reviewText: This is honestly one of my favorite HO games, not the least because I'm a Holmes fan and Hound of the Bakervilles is one of my favorite books.  However, I will warn the Sherlock purists that this game has only a very passing relationship to the book so if you're looking for a HO-version of the classic, you very well might hate this.  The story is really very different.\n\nIn terms of general gameplay this is a pretty standard game for the genre, with HO scenes mixed with minigame puzzles and the usual inventory-based puzzles.  Where it departs from the norm is with a handful of special powers" unlocked throughout the game that add to the puzzles; while in some cases it's apparent what you have to use and when
date: other times it took some thought and I appreciated that.\n\nPuzzles and minigames themselves are average difficulty
recommended: not hard but not too easy
hoursPlayed: with the exception of one or two of the minigames that were just obnoxious; however there is a skip button or if you're intent on getting a no-skip achievement
voteText: there are solutions online (I confess to being guilty of looking up one or two solutions for that reason).\n\nSound and voice acting is nothing stellar but definitely better than the average
helpfulPercent: if you consider that most HO games have extremely poor voice acting.\n\nAll in all
votesHelpful: a great game with some unique aspects that make it stand out.  Worth it if you're a fan of this style of game."

reviewText:
For a Frogwares game, this isn't bad at all. The story is appropriately ludicrous (and has nothing but the name in common with the book), but all in all it's rather inoffensive. The art is nice enough, the music and voice acting less so, but they get the job done without being jarringly bad. But most importantly, both the HOG scenes and the puzzles are decently done. I did find them to be mostly on the easier side even on the hard difficulty (with the exception of one or two puzzles towards the end that actually provided some challenge), but nonetheless they were enjoyable.

So for anyone who doesn't normally play HOGs: This might not be a good enough game to get introduced to the genre with. (Though it is much better than the average HOG slop nonetheless, which may be a useful thing to keep in mind.)

For HOG players: This is actually a fun game, with acceptable production values and enjoyable puzzles. The gameplay feels streamlined and doesn't ever get frustrating, plus it has some decent length. I'd still wait for a discount, but ymmv.

Keep in mind that if you're playing with smaller children you may wonna pre-screen. There are no real scares, but some gore, which is suspiciously absent from the Steam screenshots.

reviewText: While the game takes several liberties with the classic Arthur Conan Doyle mystery, and puts an interesting spin on it, its spirit and/or heart is in the right place. I got the sense that the developers really enjoyed creating this point and click, hidden object tale. The puzzles are done cleverly, and without being too easy or mind numbingly hard. One or two of them actually gave me pause in a good way. The colors are wonderfully lush, the atmosphere eerie, the music pretty, and the vocal talent/cast does a good job from beginning to end. Watson's dialogue is a treat in a few scenes. However, I won't spoil it for you. I finished the game within a few hours and was not disappointed in the least. Enjoy & Happy Gaming! :)

reviewText:
Sherlock Holmes and the Hound of the Baskervilles			* 7/10
Another Hidden Object adventure involving Sherlock Holmes in one of his famous stories from the homonymous original novel. This time Frogware is just a publisher not the developer and this choice is evident in many ways inside the game.

This short adventure starts With Henry Baskerville asking Sherlock Holmes to help him to break the curse of his family which involves a big Hound that brutally kills all of the Baskerville family members from generations. Now, for those who are familiar with Sherlock Holmes and the original novel, yes: this is not exactly a faithful transposition but it's more like an interpretation... Which works good and bad at the same time. Good beccause the adventure in a big mansion where a Demonic dog is supposed to be is quite a good idea giving the game a good dark atmosphere. Bad because this interpretation involves magic and time travel (without any particular consequence, so it's just an excuse to have another room with riddles with a few minor graphic differences), which really don't belong in a Sherlock Holmes adventure.
As a Hidden Object game The gameplay doesn't need much explanation. You need to explore rooms or other ambiences, pick up items, interact with various objects and when you focus on determined zones you will be requested to find a long list of items very well hidden in the screen. Besides that you can find a very long list of puzzles and riddels, some of them are quite easy, but there are few VERY TOUGHT ones that forced me to get some help to deal with them.
This title can count on a good soundtrack most of the times trying to give a tense atmosphere, maybe even more than necessary. Besides that Holmes, Watson and Henry Baskerville will often talk during the adventure and not just with captions as already happened with the persian carpet, but we can hear the original voice cast for our two protagonist, which is really appreciated.
The worst side of this title I believe is the menu and game system, where you don't save because it's an automatic progress but you can't start a new game befor you completely finish it first unless you erase and create a new game profile... An operation that will delete your (ingame) achievements, which is the reason that took me 5 runs instead of just 2 to fully achieve the game.

+++PROs+++ GOOD ADVENTURE. All in all this title represent a good adventure, with tough Hidden Object sections, Some very Hard Puzzles and Riddles, with easier ones, various dialogues with characters and a nice soundtrack.---CONs--- MAGIC. Actually This version of the Hound of the Baskervilles doesn't really suit a Sherlock Adventure mostly because it doesn't give an explanation at the end even though for all the time Sherlock says there Must be an explanation.
SAVE SYSTEM AND MENU. This game doesn't have a way to restart the game unless you finish it first and the only way to do that is to erase your ingame profile and make a new one. But this way you will lose all your ingame achievements, and I don't recall being informed of this at the moment.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Loved this game!!!!  Played it twice already and I had forgotten how to get through many of the rooms.  That is a feat for a HOG.  There are so many things to do and not always in the same order.  There are loads of rooms, alternate realities, things to collect and puzzles to do.

I loved how the map told you that you had unfinished business in certain rooms AND when a room was completed it let you know so that you were not going there over and over to find something you think you missed.

Very interesting story and trumps almost all other Sherlock Holmes HOGs I have played.  Well worth the money, expecially since this is one to play over.  It's like getting double our money!

I recommend this for all levels.  You will not be dissapointed!

reviewText: A decent hidden object game with a decent backstory.  This is a superstition and mythical creature type of Sherlock Holmes story.  This is not your standard Sherlock Holmes.  The game features decent graphics and a good balance of hidden object / puzzle.  None of it is too hard as is the typical casual gameplay for this genre.  You won't be raving about this game, however, it's a decent enough game to warrant at least one play through.

reviewText:
Unlike most of the other Sherlock Holmes games on Steam, this is more a classic Hidden Object type game rather than Point & Click or FMV. It's a perfectly good game for its genre with good HO scenes and logic in puzzles. The puzzle type and difficulty varies greatly throughout the game; most are doable without guide or hints.

The story follows Sherlock Holmes and Doctor Watson as they go with Lord Baskerville to his mansion to find out why his bloodline has apparently been cursed and his ancestors all died to this curse by being attacked by the creature known as the Hound of the Baskerville.

As a Sherlock story it's a bit... blasphemous; the story has heavy focus on supernatural theme and there no logical solution is found (this is not really a spoiler),

The game has good visual progress with throughout the game you complete badges" to unlock powers to get into new rooms. Not really sure if this is good or not as it reminded me a bit too much of the much more child-friendly Princess Isabella games.

All achievements are easily earned; the one it says you get for "completing the game" is actually earned for Easy mode only
date: and as it has an achievement for completing Hard mode
recommended: you'll have to play it through twice to get all achievements. All dialogues can be skipped and as I accidentally clicked away a sentence said by a character
hoursPlayed: I can only assume that the "do not skip" achievement is only messed up if you click "skip" on dialogues entirely and not for normal left-click for skipping the sayings individually.\n\nI didn't have too much problem with the voice-acting; Sherlock is a bit more enthusiastic in this game than he is in the later P&C games Testament and Crimes and Punishment. The sound effects and music is pretty good
voteText: but if you play League of Legends it might annoy you that in one musictrack there are sounds almost identical to "found a game" and "game invite" in LoL.\n\nBuy more for the Hidden Object genre than for it being a Sherlock Holmes game. You may wanna buy it on a discount as it's getting a bit old
helpfulPercent: but it's a very enjoyable game."

reviewText:
Another HOG title from Frogware and another based around Sherlock Holmes. Any hard-headed fan of the books should probably stop and not look too hard at the plot here which bases itself around mystical murders, summoning, magic, dimension hopping and ghostly goings on. Its less Sherlock and more Doctor Who style of a story.

In any case I probably should talk about the gameplay, the whole thing plays as a mix between an Adventure title and a casual Hidden Object game. As such theres a good amount of scenes where you have to scour for items, however theres also a good amount of puzzles to back the whole thing up. Theres nothing too difficult here but the scenes are varied and colourful enough and the game runs by at a fast enough pace to avoid players being too bored.

Essentially if you dont mind the odd Hidden Object title, its one to pick up. If you cant stand Hidden Object titles however, theres nothing for you here. I think thats about as simple as I can put it.

reviewText:
Short version: 84%A very simplistic hidden object puzzle game with a good name attached to it, Hound of the Baskervilles offers a quite interesting take on the famous novel.

Long version:Letâ€™s get this right out of the way: if you are a Sherlock Holmes purist, stay far away from this. Apart from the presence of Sir Henry Baskerville this game has nothing to do with the novelâ€“ not only the titular hellhound is an actual demon, but Holmes even uses magical powers to battle it.
Despite this rather unique use of artistic freedom, the writing is the main strength of this title: both the short plot and the large number of dialogues are great and the actors do an excellent job as well.

The game itself is just a glorified item gathering: you visit rooms to collect things either from the scenery or by playing meticulously crafted hidden object scenes, assemble them into some fairly challenging puzzles, which reward you with even more items. This pattern is repeated from start to finish with not change in the concept.
Donâ€™t be fooled though, the game isnâ€™t easy. It is aimed at the more experienced hidden object players, who will undoubtedly have several hours of great fun with it.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you've ever read the book, then you'll probably have a hard time playing over the sound of Arthur Conan Doyle spinning in his grave.
The 'story' (for a hidden object game) feels like the developers read the first two chapters, got the premise (American tycoon goes to live in a supposedly cursed mansion, gets Holmes to help) and then proceeded to have a fever dream.
Gameplay is essentially just completing hidden object screens and solving simplistic puzzles, many of which are copied directly from other Waterlily games.
Watson sounds alright, but Sir Henry's voice acting is as flat as a pancake, and Frogwares' Holmes actor sounds distant and condescending.

Overall, if the Sherlock Holmes licence wasn't attached to this game and its plot, it would be semi-viable, but as it is, the licence has been maimed by the sheer absurdity of the mumbo-jumbo proceedings.

reviewText:
An excellent hidden object game.

This simple title provides several hours of engrossing puzzles. The story, voice acting and graphics are a tad corny, making it seem more like a Scooby Doo episode than a true Sherlock Holmes mystery. However, the puzzles were very well done, and the game did a good job of pacing itself and keeping me interested.

Bottom line: I'd recommend it if you're looking for an enjoyable diversion that will only last an evening or two.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Normally I am not much into hidden object games. More an Adventure/RPG type of gamer. But this game is done very well. It is very loosely based on 'The Hound of the Baskervilles' (actually so loosely that it has little to do with it ), however the creators just made a game that is fun to play and that is more important than trying to make a game realistic or following some story.

Contrary to most adventure/casual games this has quite a lot of different kind of puzzles. For instance, one based on planar graphs, a puzzle based on rotating groups of tiles (which I found the most difficult yet solvable after a little thought), a few about identifying objects in a scene etc. It is nice to see a game with such a variety. The renderings are awesome. Don't expect much animation though the game is mainly still pictures with some animation happening when you solve a puzzle but the game still looks gorgeous.

Another thing is that the game isn't too easy yet can be solved without a walkthrough. There are also buttons that let you skip a puzzle when you are stuck or ask for help. I skipped one puzzle ( the one where you have to compare, the painting of a vase, to the 'real thing' and find the differences) because I needed to quit).

I clocked in about 16 hours.

reviewText: This game was enjoyable enough that I did a second run on easy to get all achievements (you don't get the easy achievements for completing the game on hard difficulty). Both settings are enjoyable,with the hard setting throwing a couple decent challenges at you.\n\nIf you look at this game as a typical adventure game, it does its job well. The puzzles were about the right difficulty, you had to combine items you had gotten before, use the amulet powers" and you can beat the game using only your logic. I do not care much for the highlight object mini-games though
date: since most of the time you find the item you want easily but still have to collect random stuff like lamps and feathers for no apparent reason.\n\nThe pallete and textures are decent and most of the items in the highlight object mini-games can be seen clearly. Some are harder to see
recommended:
but still it is more an issue of clever use of environment rather than not being able to distinguish something from the environment (unlike previous games like Dracula: Origin).

WARNING: The following contains spoilers.

Much like Baskerville Hall
hoursPlayed: not everything is sunny though. My biggest problem is how the source material is used. As I said
voteText: this is a solid adventure game
helpfulPercent: but not a very good Sherlock Holmes story. There are supernatural elements that are left unexplained
votesHelpful: the main plot is not given a rational explanation as one would expect from Holmes and so on. I was very dissapointed by the ending
votesTotal: but it became apparent in the middle of the game that either this must be a dream or there is no way that there is a rational explanation for all of this. Even if we ignore this and treat this as a typical non-Holmes detective story
votesFunny: there is not a final verdict on who used the hound or something like that (in contrast to the book). In the end
commentsCount: you feel more like a ghost hunter than a detective.\n\nIf you are a casual adventure games player this game is worth it
column16: especially if you find it on sale or bundled. I am afraid hardcore adventure players will just breeze through it
column17: so only get it if you have finished harder games and want to kill some time. Sherlock Holmes fans should probably best avoid it
column18: since the source material is not treated well.\n\nFinally
column19: one can see that Frogwares has evolved from earlies titles and continues to evolve to the much better "Testament of Sherlock Holmes". I am at least happy to see this as a stepping stone towards a better future for a small developer."

reviewText:
If you're trying to learn about Sherlock Holmes, this is the wrong place to start. It takes the basic plot of the novel (demonic dog targets family) and then goes batshit crazy with it. Fortunately, they do it in such a fun way that I don't think it detracts from the game at all.

It's a very good-looking point-and-click game with some pretty good puzzles and very good pacing. Sure, there are too many Hidden Objects puzzles, but those are so easy and short that I was never annoyed by it. Puzzles vary in difficulty and there are a few types of puzzles that make a second appearance, but there's still a lot of variation.

The music is a bit overly dramatic, but certainly not bad. Not memorable either, though. Controls and the map work really well and the whole thing is well executed, although the dialogue and cinematics are mediocre.

Still, all the parts you actually play are a lot of fun, provided you don't worry about canon or taking things too seriously.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I didn't have high expectations for this game, but I was pleasantly surprised. This is a hidden object, casual puzzle-solving game done right. The hidden object scenes are logical. They aren't just a random garbage dump of items; everything on the screen has a reason to be there. The puzzles are quite easy for the most part (with one devlishly hard one thrown in there for some reason). Only once did I feel any frustration (on that one crazy hard puzzle), and a quick visit to the internet helped me find the solution and carry on.\n\nThe game is quite short, though, and not much of a challenge. Best suited to truly casual gamers. The story felt a little forced at times, and as a fan of the actual Sherlock Holmes books, I was disappointed with the lack of logic and overabundance of mystical forces. Still, setting that aside, it was an enjoyable few hours and I don't regret getting the game, especially since I got it as part of a bundle and it cost less than $1.

reviewText:
Overall: Got this in a bundle and enjoyed it but I would probably not pay full price for it if I had to.

- This is a short game but it's not horrible.

- It was the first of the Sherlock Holmes games that I had played, but I am a fan of hidden object puzzles so I had a good time. The other puzzles were not very challenging, though at least the solutions were usually pretty self explanatory.

- Voice acting is decent; music is dramatic but it fits the feel of the game.

* Note: If you play the game on easy mode, it will guide you to the next step (the area you should click starts sparkling) if you wait for more than 10 seconds or so. Can be helpful if stuck but can possibly be annoying if you are just pausing for a second to do something else.

reviewText:
Recomended only for Hidden Object Games Fans.

It may be a Sherlock Holmes game but the puzzles cannot stand up to his name. If you have played other of Frogwares' games you will find a lot of simularities in them. The hidden objects are well blended in the background and not impossible to find. You can do them without a single hint if you want to spend the time on it.

About the story, it barely has anything to do with the novel. It is completely made up and really off Arthur Conan Doyle's style. And regardless of that it kept me going until the end, even if it was very predictable.

The music and graphics are very impressive. There is only one track going on during the whole game but it is long enough to annoy you. The vocing is well directed and well executed. The characters and the layouts have a lot of effort put in the details and are just gorgeous.

The game can be finsihed for less then 5 hours with or without hints. And the only replay value comes from completing the achievments.

I got the game in a bundle and I wasn't going to buy it if it wasn't in it, but have in mind I dislike Hidden Object Games, but I still enjoyed it.

reviewText: If you enjoy this type of games, you can't go wrong with this one. Unlike the terrible Sherlock Holmes: Mystery of Persian Carpet, this game is vastly improved in every way. Story is without a doubt the weakest link, but would you really expect a respectful interpretation of the original story in hidden objects game? It's fine and if you accept it for what it is, it's really not that bad, just think of it as a non-canon supernatural tour through the Baskerville manor.\n\nGameplay is great, difficulty is quite low, which is fine by me, I don't want to be stuck for too long on strange puzzles or impossible to see objects. Achievements are nice as well, motivates you to do them, since they're not too hard. Overall I've thoroughly enjoyed playing it.

reviewText:
Let's be honest, it's a Hidden Object game. It succeeds very well in being a Hidden Object game. Most of the puzzles can be solved with a bit of logic, but if you've played some of the puzzle games like Professor Layton or Puzzle Agent, you'll be able to solve many by memory, rather than logic. Most of the hidden object areas aren't the hardest and there's a good hint system to help you out.
Voice acting seems to be by the same guys who do Watson and Holmes in the other Frogwares games, if you're particularly attached to them.
If you like Hidden Object games, this is probably a game that you will enjoy for a few horus.
(PS... This isn't exactly how the real story goes... This is more... Sherlock Holmes with superpowers and time travel... But hey, Sherlock Holmes with superpowers and time travel, right!?)

reviewText: I just can't quite recommend this one. The supernatural story is an affront to Holmesian reason, the voice actors are poorly cast, and the visuals are often of poor quality. Moreover, the hidden object scenes are roughshod and the puzzles range from dirt simple to frustratingly unintuitive. There are certainly some redeeming qualities here and there - an excellent map, for example - but the overall experience is just a little sub-par.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Not the best hidden object game out there, but good enough that you'll want to finish it.  It does have a couple interesting tack-ons, such as the Elements, and a couple tough puzzles, particularly towards the end.

Art is decent and I didn't find the HO scenes too dark, which can absolutely ruin a HO game.

There are only two difficulty levels - Easy and Hard.  Hard is more like Casual in other HO games.  Hints are available, and without penalty, an auto-hint will alert your next move if you take too long in a room, and the map notates rooms that have a current puzzle or object available.

As a couple others have stated, the story is rather ludicrous, but worst is the voice acting.  Now, Frogwares, I'm sure you didn't have a large budget for the voice acting, but you could have at least had the actors slow down a little and use the punctuation properly when they were speaking.  It was like they were speed reading the script.

Lastly, I was very disappointed with the end.  It just kind of...ended.

reviewText: So on one hand, the art is VERY well done, and the puzzles aren't bad. reviewText: I am playing and reviewing Frogware's Sherlock Holmes series in chronological order of the games. This game is considered a casual adventure game and it is unclear if this game is considered cannon or not. This game is made and could chronilogically be after Sherlock Versus Jack the Ripper.\n\nThe issue is that at the end of Sherlock Versus Jack the Ripper the Sherlock told Dr. Watson to cover up Jack the Ripper's story with a story about magical hounds refering to the story The Hounds of Baskerville. Playing this game could have easily be fiction" in the Sherlock universe to cover this up
date: however during the game Watson refers to the Jack the Ripper case in this game thus putting this game in a type of limbo within Frogware's Sherlock Holmes universe.\n\nAfter playing Sherlock Holmes: Mystery of the Persian Carpet
recommended: I was cautious to play another point and click adventure game by Frogware. I was happily suprised immediately when I start the game that all my worries were for not. Frogware fixed everything that was wrong with the Persian Carpet. There are slight animations instead of still frames
voteText: and unique setting and puzzles. This game is probably one of the best examples of a point and click adventure and hidden object game. You need to find hidden objects and then some of those found objects are used and combined to solve another puzzle.\n\nThe graphics are great

reviewText:
Pros:+ excellent quality graphics
+ very good sound design and music
+ very user-friendly gameplay - two difficulty levels, auto-navigation map
+ uses the same excellent HOPA engine as Dracula: Love Kills
+ the voice acting is way better than in DLK, which is strange as this game came sooner
+ loving the special abilities, they enrich the usual HOPA gameplay
+ many achievements

Cons:- a single random and pointless jumpscare
- some of the sound effects are annoying
- predictable plot
- confusing family tree, too many names

Verdict:Good quality HOPA game, get it, especially if you haven't played Dracula: Love Kills. Unfortunately they repeated many of the puzzles and music tracks of this game in that one.
